	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company also has a referral agreement in place with CCRE, in which brokers are incentivized
	to refer business to CCRE through a revenue-share arrangement. In connection with this revenue-share agreement, the Company recognized revenues of $2.0 million, $1.2 million and $1.5 million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013,
	respectively. This revenue was recorded as part of &#147;Commissions&#148; in the Company&#146;s consolidated statements of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Cantor Rights to Purchase Limited Partnership Interests from BGC Holdings
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cantor has the right to purchase limited partnership interests (Cantor units) from BGC Holdings upon redemption of non-exchangeable FPUs
	redeemed by BGC Holdings upon termination or bankruptcy of the founding/working partner. Any such Cantor units purchased by Cantor are exchangeable for shares of Class B common stock or, at Cantor&#146;s election or if there are no additional
	authorized but unissued shares of Class B common stock, shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock, in each case on a one-for-one basis (subject to customary anti-dilution adjustments).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On July&nbsp;21, 2014, the Company issued exchange rights with respect to, and Cantor purchased, an aggregate of 3,142,257 exchangeable
	limited partnership units in BGC Holdings consisting of (i)&nbsp;1,371,058 such units in connection with the redemption by BGC Holdings of an aggregate of 1,371,058 non-exchangeable founding partner units from former Cantor partners who were former
	founding partners of BGC Holdings, and (ii)&nbsp;1,771,199 such units in connection with the grant of exchangeability to 1,771,199 units held by former Cantor partners who were former founding partners of BGC Holdings. Such exchangeable limited
	partnership units were exchangeable by Cantor at any time on a one-for-one basis for shares of common stock of the Company. The aggregate net purchase price paid by Cantor for such units was $10.6 million. Immediately after Cantor&#146;s purchases
	of such exchangeable limited partnership units, also on July&nbsp;21, 2014, the Company purchased from Cantor an aggregate of 5&nbsp;million units and shares, consisting of (i)&nbsp;all of such 3,142,257 units and (ii)&nbsp;1,857,743 previously
	owned shares of the Company&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common stock, for $38.7 million based on the closing price per share of the Class&nbsp;A common stock on the date of such purchases.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On November&nbsp;4, 2015, the Company issued exchange rights with respect to, and Cantor purchased, in transactions exempt from registration
	pursuant to Section&nbsp;4(a)(2) of the Securities Act, an aggregate of 1,775,481 exchangeable limited partnership units in BGC Holdings, as follows: In connection with the redemption by BGC Holdings of an aggregate of 588,356 non-exchangeable
	founding partner units from founding partners of BGC Holdings for an aggregate consideration of $2,296,801, Cantor purchased 554,196 exchangeable limited partnership units from BGC Holdings for an aggregate of $2,115,306 (after offset of a founding
	partner&#146;s $46,289 debt due to Cantor). In addition, pursuant to the Sixth Amendment to the BGC Holdings Limited Partnership Agreement, on November&nbsp;4, 2015 Cantor purchased 1,221,285 exchangeable limited partnership units from BGC Holdings
	for an aggregate consideration of $4,457,436 in connection with the grant of exchangeability and exchange of 1,221,285 founding partner units. Exchangeable limited partnership units held by Cantor are exchangeable by Cantor at any time on a
	one-for-one basis (subject to adjustment) for shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock of the Company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, there
	were 219,270 non-exchangeable FPUs remaining in which BGC Holdings had the right to redeem and Cantor had the right to purchase an equivalent number of Cantor units.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Transactions with Executive Officers and Directors
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, the Company repurchased 33,478 shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock, at an average price of $5.61
	per share, from Stephen M. Merkel, the Company&#146;s Executive Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary, and 533,406 shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock, at an average price of $5.82 per share, from Shaun D. Lynn, the Company&#146;s President.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In connection with the Global Partnership Restructuring Program during the second quarter of 2013, the Company redeemed/exchanged a total
	of 9,930,675 previously issued limited partnership units for 3,553,345 shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock and 3,561,392 shares of restricted stock from the Company&#146;s executive officers. The number of shares delivered to the executive officers
	was net of 1,028,128 shares withheld to pay withholding taxes. These shares were awarded to the executive officers on July&nbsp;30, 2013. In connection with the Global Partnership Restructuring Program, Mr.&nbsp;Lutnick elected to exercise certain
	cumulative rights previously granted to him with respect to an aggregate of 1,802,608 of his non-exchangeable partnership units, which resulted in the receipt of shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock for such units.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In addition, in connection with the foregoing, Messrs. Lynn, Windeatt and Sadler received an aggregate of 283,206 newly-issued BGC Holdings
	limited partnership units (equivalent to 9.75% of their non-exchangeable units that were redeemed in the above transactions). Upon any sale or other transfer by such executive officers of shares of restricted stock, a proportional number of these
	limited partnership units will be redeemed for zero by BGC Holdings. These units are not exchangeable into shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On January&nbsp;21, 2014, the Compensation Committee authorized the acceleration of restrictions with respect to an aggregate of 1,254,723
	shares of restricted Class&nbsp;A common stock held by the Company&#146;s executive officers as follows: Mr.&nbsp;Lutnick, 628,872 shares (Mr. Lutnick does not currently intend to sell any of these shares); Mr.&nbsp;Lynn, 424,347 shares;
	Mr.&nbsp;Merkel, 14,689 shares; Mr.&nbsp;Windeatt, 146,843 shares; and Mr.&nbsp;Sadler, 39,972 shares. The Compensation Committee authorized the Company to repurchase any or all of such shares from the executive officers at a price of $6.51 per
	share, which was the closing price of our Class&nbsp;A common stock on January&nbsp;21, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D77592D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On February&nbsp;5, 2014, certain executive officers elected to sell, and we agreed to purchase,
	an aggregate of 636,841 shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock from such executive officers at a price of $6.51 per share as follows: Mr.&nbsp;Lynn, 424,347 shares; Mr.&nbsp;Merkel, 14,689 shares; Mr.&nbsp;Windeatt, 157,833 shares (of which 146,843
	shares were previously restricted and an additional 10,990 freely tradable shares); and Mr.&nbsp;Sadler, 39,972 shares.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On May&nbsp;9,
	2014, partners of BGC Holdings approved the Tenth Amendment to the Agreement of Limited Partnership of BGC Holdings (the &#147;Tenth Amendment&#148;) effective as of May&nbsp;9, 2014. In order to facilitate partner compensation and for other
	corporate purposes the Tenth Amendment creates a new class of partnership units (&#147;NPSUs&#148;), which are working partner units.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	NPSUs are not entitled to participate in Partnership distributions, will not be allocated any items of profit or loss and may not be made
	exchangeable into shares of the Company&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common stock. Subject to the approval of the Compensation Committee or its designee, N Units are expected to be exchanged for the underlying unit type (i.e. an NREU will be converted into
	an REU) and will then participate in Partnership distributions, subject to terms and conditions determined by the General Partner of the Partnership in its sole discretion, including that the recipient continue to provide substantial services to the
	Company and comply with his or her partnership obligations. The Tenth Amendment was approved by the Audit Committee of the Board of Directors and by the full Board of Directors.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On January&nbsp;1, 2015, (i)&nbsp;1,000,000 of Mr.&nbsp;Lutnick&#146;s NPSUs converted into 550,000 PSUs and 450,000 PPSUs, of which
	Mr.&nbsp;Lutnick has the right to exchange for shares and cash, which he waived under our policy (described below), 239,739 PSUs and 196,150 PPSUs, and (ii)&nbsp;142,857 of Mr.&nbsp;Merkel&#146;s NPSUs converted into 78,571 PSUs and 64,286 PPSUs, of
	which 5,607 PSUs and 4,588 PPSUs were made exchangeable and repurchased by the Company at the average price of shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock sold under our Controlled Equity Offering less 2%, or $91,558.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On January&nbsp;30, 2015, the Compensation Committee granted 4,000,000 NPSUs to Mr.&nbsp;Lutnick and 1,000,000 NPSUs to Mr.&nbsp;Lynn.
	One-quarter of the NPSUs vested on January&nbsp;1, 2016 and were converted into an equivalent number PSUs/PPSUs for Mr.&nbsp;Lutnick and LPUs/PLPUs for Mr.&nbsp;Lynn on such date.&nbsp;Subject to the approval of the Compensation Committee each year,
	the remaining NPSUs may be converted pro rata into an equivalent number of PSUs/PPSUs for Mr.&nbsp;Lutnick and LPUs/PLPUs for Mr.&nbsp;Lynn on January&nbsp;1 of each year beginning on January&nbsp;1, 2017 and ending January&nbsp;1, 2020. The grant
	of exchange rights with respect to such PSUs/PPSUs and LPUs/PLPUs will be determined in accordance with the Company&#146;s practices when determining discretionary bonuses or awards, which may include the Compensation Committee&#146;s exercise of
	negative discretion to reduce or withhold any such awards.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Transactions with Relief Fund
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, the Company issued and donated an aggregate of 1,000,000 shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock to
	The Cantor Fitzgerald Relief Fund (the &#147;Relief Fund&#148;) in connection with the Company&#146;s annual Charity Day. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, the Company made a $1.0 million payment to the Relief Fund in connection with the
	Company&#146;s annual Charity Day. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company issued an interest-free loan to the Relief Fund for $1.0 million in connection with the Company&#146;s annual Charity Day. As a result of the loan, the
	Relief Fund issued a promissory note to the Company to repay the principal of $1.0 million on August&nbsp;4, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the years ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2013, the Company committed to make charitable contributions to the Relief Fund in the amounts of $40.0 million and $25.0 million, respectively, which the Company recorded in &#147;Other expenses&#148; in the
	Company&#146;s consolidated statements of operations for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2013, respectively. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the remaining liability associated with these commitments was $55.5 million, which is included in
	&#147;Accounts payable, accrued and other liabilities&#148; in the Company&#146;s consolidated statements of financial condition.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Other Transactions
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company is authorized to enter into loans, investments or other credit support arrangements for Aqua Securities L.P. (&#147;Aqua&#148;), an
	alternative electronic trading platform that offers new pools of block liquidity to the global equities markets, such arrangements are proportionally and on the same terms as similar arrangements between Aqua and Cantor. On October&nbsp;27, 2015,
	the Company&#146;s Board of Directors and Audit Committee increased the authorized amount by an additional $4.0 million, to $15.6 million. The Company has been further authorized to provide counterparty or similar guarantees on behalf of Aqua from
	time to time, provided that liability for any such guarantees, as well as similar guarantees provided by Cantor, would be shared proportionally with Cantor. Aqua is 51% owned by Cantor and 49% owned by the Company. Aqua is accounted for under the
	equity method of accounting. During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, the Company made $1.3 million and $0.9 million, respectively, in cash contributions to Aqua. These contributions are recorded as part of &#147;Investments&#148; in
	the Company&#146;s consolidated statements of financial condition.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has also entered into a Subordinated Loan Agreement with
	Aqua, whereby the Company agreed to lend Aqua the principal sum of $980 thousand. The scheduled maturity date on the subordinated loan is September&nbsp;1, 2017, and the current rate of interest on the loan is three month LIBOR plus 600 basis
	points. The loan to Aqua is recorded as part of &#147;Receivables from related parties&#148; in the Company&#146;s consolidated statements of financial condition.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	153
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage156"></A>

<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8.0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;WIDTH:10%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE:85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN:TOP">
	1
</SUP>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE:85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN:TOP">
</SUP>
	Represents the Company&#146;s voting interest in the equity method investment as of December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company recognized a gain of $0.8 million, and losses of $8.6 million and $9.5 million related to its equity method investments for the
	years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014, and 2013, respectively. The Company&#146;s share of the gains or losses is reflected in &#147;Gains (losses) on equity method investments&#148; in the Company&#146;s consolidated statements of operations. As
	a result of the GFI acquisition, the Company also had certain investments in brokerage businesses in which the Company had a contractual right to receive a percentage of revenues, less certain direct expenses. The Company accounted for these
	investments in a manner similar to the equity method of accounting. The sale of KBL (see Note 5&#150;&#147;Divestitures&#148;) in May 2015 included these investments. Through the date of sale, the Company&#146;s share of gain on these investments
	was $1.0 million. The Company&#146;s total share of gains and losses is reflected in &#147;Gains (losses) on equity method investments&#148; in the Company&#146;s consolidated statement of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In June 2013, the Company acquired a controlling interest in an entity that had previously been accounted for using the equity method. This
	transaction resulted in the consolidation of the entity in the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements. In June 2014, the Company acquired a 10% interest in a limited liability corporation (see Note 14&#151;&#147;Related Party
	Transactions&#148; for more information).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On December&nbsp;23, 2014, ELX, which had previously been accounted for using the equity
	method, was consolidated into the Company&#146;s financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Summarized condensed financial information for the Company&#146;s
	equity method investments is as follows (in thousands):
</P>

	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Investments in Variable Interest Entities
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Certain of the Company&#146;s equity method investments included in the tables above are considered Variable Interest Entities
	(&#147;VIEs&#148;), as defined under the accounting guidance for consolidation. The Company is not considered the primary beneficiary of, and therefore does not consolidate, these VIEs. The Company&#146;s involvement with such entities is in the
	form of direct equity interests and related agreements. The Company&#146;s maximum exposure to loss with respect to the VIEs is its investment in such entities as well as a credit facility and a subordinated loan.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	154
</P>

</TR>

<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8.0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;WIDTH:10%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE:85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN:TOP">
	1
</SUP>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	The Company has entered into a subordinated loan agreement with a VIE (Aqua), whereby the Company agreed to lend the principal sum of $980 thousand. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company&#146;s maximum exposure to
	loss with respect to its VIEs includes the sum of its equity investments in its unconsolidated VIEs and the $980 thousand subordinated loan to Aqua.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Consolidated VIE
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Through the acquisition of GFI, the Company is invested in a limited company that is focused on developing a proprietary trading business. The
	limited company is a VIE and it was determined that the Company is the primary beneficiary of this VIE because the Company, through GFI, was the provider of the majority of this VIE&#146;s start-up capital and has the power to direct the activities
	of this VIE that most significantly impact its economic performance, primarily through its voting percentage and consent rights on the activities that would most significantly influence the entity. The consolidated VIE had total assets of $9.5
	million at December&nbsp;31, 2015, which primarily consisted of clearing margin. There were no material restrictions on the consolidated VIE&#146;s assets. The consolidated VIE had total liabilities of $1.5 million at December&nbsp;31, 2015. The
	Company&#146;s exposure to economic loss on this VIE is approximately $5.8 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Cost Method Investments
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As a result of the GFI acquisition, the Company acquired investments for which it did not have the ability to exert significant influence over
	operating and financial policies. These investments are generally accounted for using the cost method of accounting in accordance with ASC 325-10, Investments&#151;Other. At December&nbsp;31, 2015, the carrying value of these cost method investments
	was $1.5 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Depreciation expense was $31.9 million, $29.1 million and $32.7 million for the years ended December&nbsp;31,
	2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively. Depreciation is included as part of &#147;Occupancy and equipment&#148; in the Company&#146;s consolidated statements of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has approximately $6.4 million of asset retirement obligations related to certain of its leasehold improvements. The associated
	asset retirement cost is capitalized as part of the carrying amount of the long-lived asset. The liability is discounted and accretion expense is recognized using the credit adjusted risk-free interest rate in effect when the liability was initially
	recognized.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, software development costs totaling $18.5 million, $12.7 million
	and $15.0 million, respectively, were capitalized. Amortization of software development costs totaled $22.9 million, $11.4 million and $9.0 million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively. Amortization of software
	development costs is included as part of &#147;Occupancy and equipment&#148; in the Company&#146;s consolidated statements of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Impairment charges of $19.1 million, $4.2 million and $6.1 million were recorded for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013,
	respectively, related to the evaluation of capitalized software projects for future benefit and for fixed assets no longer in service. In connection with the acquisition of GFI, the Company evaluated the combined portfolios of capitalized software
	projects and fixed assets and, as a result, identified certain redundancies and assets no longer in service which resulted in impairment charges. The impairment charges for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014 were related to the
	Financial Services segment. Impairment charges related to capitalized software and fixed assets are reflected in &#147;Occupancy and equipment&#148; in the Company&#146;s consolidated statements of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company recognized additional goodwill of approximately
	$453.8 million and $127.7 million, which was allocated to the Company&#146;s Financial Services segment and the Company&#146;s Real Estate Services segment, respectively. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, the Company recognized
	additional goodwill of approximately $52.0 million and $180.6 million, which was allocated to the Company&#146;s Financial Services segment and the Company&#146;s Real Estate Services segment, respectively. See Note 4&#151;&#147;Acquisitions&#148;
	for more information.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company completed the sale of its Trayport business, which is
	reflected in the reductions of goodwill recorded at the Company&#146;s Financial Services segment. See Note 5&#151;&#147;Divestitures&#148; for more information.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company recognized measurement period adjustments of approximately $(2.7) million relating
	to Financial Services, and $7.5 million for Real Estate Services. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, the Company recognized measurement period adjustments of approximately $0.2 million relating to Financial Services, and $(1.1) million
	for Real Estate Services. The Company considers the adjustments insignificant to its consolidated financial statements and accordingly the Company&#146;s consolidated statements of financial condition at December&nbsp;31, 2014 and December&nbsp;31,
	2013, were not retrospectively adjusted.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Goodwill is not amortized and is reviewed annually for impairment or more frequently if
	impairment indicators arise, in accordance with FASB guidance on Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets. The Company completed its annual goodwill impairment testing during the fourth quarter of 2015, which did not result in any goodwill impairment.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	156
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Intangible amortization expense was $27.2 million, $4.2 million and $5.5 million for the years ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively. Intangible amortization is included as part of &#147;Other expenses&#148; in the Company&#146;s consolidated statements of operations.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The fair value of the 8.75% Convertible Notes was estimated based on a jump-diffusion convertible pricing
	model, which among other inputs incorporates the scheduled coupon and principal payments, the conversion feature inherent in the 8.75% Convertible Notes, the Company&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common stock price and a stock price volatility assumption. The
	stock price volatility assumptions are based on the historic volatility of the Company&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common stock. The fair value measurements of the 8.75% Convertible Notes are based on significant inputs observable in the market and are
	considered Level 2 within the fair value hierarchy. The fair values of the Senior Notes and 4.50% Convertible Notes were determined using observable market prices as these securities are traded and are considered Level 1 and Level 2, respectively,
	within the fair value hierarchy, based on whether they are deemed to be actively traded.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Convertible Notes
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On April&nbsp;1, 2010, BGC Holdings issued an aggregate of $150.0 million principal amount of the 8.75% Convertible Notes to Cantor in a
	private placement transaction. The Company used the proceeds of the 8.75% Convertible Notes to repay $150.0 million principal amount of Senior Notes that matured on April&nbsp;1, 2010. The 8.75% Convertible Notes were senior unsecured obligations
	and ranked equally and ratably with all existing and future senior unsecured obligations of the Company. The 8.75% Convertible Notes bore an annual interest rate of 8.75%, payable semi-annually in arrears on April&nbsp;15 and October&nbsp;15 of each
	year, beginning on October&nbsp;15, 2010. On April&nbsp;13, 2015, the Company&#146;s 8.75% Convertible Notes were fully converted into 24,042,599 shares of the Company&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common stock, par value $0.01 per share, and issued to Cantor
	Fitzgerald L.P. The Company recorded interest expense related to the 8.75% Convertible Notes of $3.8 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and $13.1 million for the years ending December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On July&nbsp;29, 2011, the Company issued an aggregate of $160.0 million principal amount of 4.50% Convertible Notes due 2016. The 4.50%
	Convertible Notes are general senior unsecured obligations of the Company. The 4.50% Convertible Notes pay interest semiannually at a rate of 4.50%&nbsp;per annum and were priced at par. The 4.50% Convertible Notes will mature on July&nbsp;15, 2016,
	unless earlier repurchased, exchanged or converted. The Company recorded interest expense related to the 4.50% Convertible Notes of $12.0 million, $11.9 million and $11.7 million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013,
	respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the 4.50% Convertible Notes were convertible, at the holder&#146;s option, at a conversion
	rate of 101.6260 shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock per $1,000 principal amount of notes, subject to adjustment in certain circumstances, including stock dividends and stock splits on the Class&nbsp;A common stock and the Company&#146;s payment of
	a quarterly cash dividend in excess of $0.17 per share of Class&nbsp;A common stock. Upon conversion, the Company will pay or deliver cash, shares of the Company&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common stock, or a combination thereof at the Company&#146;s
	election. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the 4.50% Convertible Notes were convertible into approximately 16.3&nbsp;million shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As prescribed by FASB guidance,
<I>
	Debt
</I>
	, the Company recognized the value of the embedded conversion feature of the 4.50% Convertible
	Notes as an increase to &#147;Additional paid-in capital&#148; of approximately $19.0 million on a pre-tax basis ($16.1 million net of taxes and issuance costs). The embedded conversion feature was measured as the difference between the proceeds
	received and the fair value of a similar liability without the conversion feature. The value of the conversion feature is treated as a debt discount and reduced the initial carrying value of the 4.50% Convertible Notes to $137.2 million, net of debt
	issuance costs of $3.8 million allocated to the debt component of the instrument. The discount is amortized as interest cost and the carrying value of the 4.50% Convertible Notes will accrete up to the face amount over the term of the 4.50%
	Convertible Notes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	158
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage161"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D77592D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In connection with the offering of the 4.50% Convertible Notes, the Company entered into capped
	call transactions, which are expected to reduce the potential dilution of the Company&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common stock upon any conversion of the 4.50% Convertible Notes in the event that the market value per share of the Company&#146;s Class&nbsp;A
	common stock, as measured under the terms of the capped call transactions, is greater than the strike price of the capped call transactions ($10.78 as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, subject to adjustment in certain circumstances). The capped call
	transactions had a cap price equal to $13.48 per share as of December&nbsp;31, 2015. The purchase price of the capped call transactions resulted in a decrease to &#147;Additional paid-in capital&#148; of $11.4 million on a pre-tax basis ($9.9
	million on an after-tax basis). The capped call transactions cover approximately 14.8&nbsp;million shares of BGC&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common stock as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, subject to adjustment in certain circumstances.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	8.125% Senior Notes
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On June&nbsp;26, 2012, the Company issued an aggregate of $112.5 million principal amount of 8.125% Senior Notes due 2042. The 8.125% Senior
	Notes are senior unsecured obligations of the Company. The 8.125% Senior Notes may be redeemed for cash, in whole or in part, on or after June&nbsp;26, 2017, at the Company&#146;s option, at any time and from time to time, until maturity at a
	redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount to be redeemed, plus accrued but unpaid interest on the principal amount being redeemed to, but not including, the redemption date. The 8.125% Senior Notes are listed on the New York Stock
	Exchange under the symbol &#147;BGCA.&#148; The Company used the proceeds to repay short-term borrowings under its unsecured revolving credit facility and for general corporate purposes, including acquisitions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The initial carrying value of the 8.125% Senior Notes was $108.7 million, net of debt issuance costs of $3.8 million. The issuance costs are
	amortized as interest cost, and the carrying value of the 8.125% Senior Notes will accrete up to the face amount over the term of the 8.125% Senior Notes. The Company recorded interest expense related to the 8.125% Senior Notes of $9.3 million for
	the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	5.375% Senior Notes
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On December&nbsp;9, 2014, the Company issued an aggregate of $300.0 million principal amount of 5.375% Senior Notes due 2019 (&#147;the 5.375%
	Senior Notes&#148;). The 5.375% Senior Notes are general senior unsecured obligations of the Company. These Senior Notes bear interest at a rate of 5.375%&nbsp;per year, payable in cash on June&nbsp;9 and December&nbsp;9 of each year, commencing
	June&nbsp;9, 2015. The interest rate payable on the notes will be subject to adjustments from time to time based on the debt rating assigned by specified rating agencies to the notes, as set forth in the Indenture. The 5.375% Senior Notes will
	mature on December&nbsp;9, 2019. The Company may redeem some or all of the notes at any time or from time to time for cash at certain &#147;make-whole&#148; redemption prices (as set forth in the Indenture). If a &#147;Change of Control Triggering
	Event&#148; (as defined in the Indenture) occurs, holders may require the Company to purchase all or a portion of their notes for cash at a price equal to 101% of the principal amount of the notes to be purchased plus any accrued and unpaid interest
	to, but excluding, the purchase date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	159
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage162"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D77592D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The initial carrying value of the 5.375% Senior Notes was $295.1 million, net of the discount and
	debt issuance costs of $4.9 million. The issuance costs are amortized as interest cost, and the carrying value of the 5.375% Senior Notes will accrete up to the face amount over the term of the notes. The Company recorded interest expense related to
	the 5.375% Senior Notes of $17.1 million and $1.0 million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively. There was no interest expense related to the 5.375% Senior Notes for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	8.375% Senior Notes
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As part of the GFI acquisition, the Company assumed $240.0 million in aggregate principal amount of 8.375% Senior Notes (the &#147;8.375%
	Senior Notes&#148;) due July 2018. The carrying value of these notes as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 was $255.3 million. Interest on these notes is payable, semi-annually in arrears on the 19th of January and July. Due to the cumulative effect of
	downgrades to the credit rating of GFI&#146;s 8.375% Senior Notes, the 8.375% Senior Notes were subjected to 200 basis points penalty interest. On April&nbsp;28, 2015, a subsidiary of the Company purchased from GFI approximately 43.0&nbsp;million
	new shares of GFI common stock. This increased BGC&#146;s ownership to approximately 67% of GFI&#146;s outstanding common stock and gave us the ability to control the timing and process with respect to a full merger. Also on July&nbsp;10, 2015, the
	Company guaranteed the obligations of GFI under the 8.375% Senior Notes. These actions resulted in upgrades of the credit ratings of GFI&#146;s 8.375% Senior Notes by Moody&#146;s Investors Service, Fitch Ratings Inc. and Standard&nbsp;&amp;
	Poor&#146;s, which reduced the penalty interest to 25 basis points effective July&nbsp;19, 2015. In addition, on January&nbsp;13, 2016, Moody&#146;s further upgraded the credit rating on GFI&#146;s 8.375% Senior Notes, eliminating the penalty
	interest. The Company recorded interest expense related to the 8.375% Senior Notes of $19.2 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Collateralized Borrowings
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Secured loan arrangements
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On various dates beginning in 2009 and most recently in December 2012, the Company entered into secured loan arrangements under which it
	pledged certain fixed assets as security for loans. The secured loan arrangements had fixed rates between 2.62% and 8.09%&nbsp;per annum and were repayable in consecutive monthly installments with the final payments due in December 2016. During the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, the Company prepaid $1.5 million related to the secured loan arrangements; therefore, these secured loan arrangements were not outstanding as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 or 2014. The Company recorded interest expense
	related to these secured loan arrangements of $4 thousand and $1.6 million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, and 2013 respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On March&nbsp;13, 2015, the Company entered into a new secured loan arrangement of $28.2 million under which it pledged certain fixed assets
	as security for a loan. This arrangement incurs interest at a fixed rate of 3.70% and matures on March&nbsp;13, 2019. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company had $23.0 million outstanding related to this secured loan arrangement, which includes
	$0.2 million of deferred financing costs. The value of the fixed assets pledged as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 was $11.4 million. The Company recorded interest expense related to this secured loan arrangement of $0.8 million year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Sale/leaseback transactions
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On various dates during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2010 and 2011, the Company sold certain furniture, equipment and software for $34.2
	million, net of costs and concurrently entered into agreements to lease the property back. The principal and interest on the leases were repayable in equal monthly installments for terms of 36 months (software) and 48 months (furniture and
	equipment) with maturities through September 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, the Company terminated the leases and
	prepaid the outstanding balance of $7.2 million. Because the leases were terminated during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, the Company had no outstanding balance or fixed assets related to the leases as of December&nbsp;31, 2014 nor
	December&nbsp;31, 2015. The Company recorded interest expense of $0.7 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Credit
	Agreement
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On June&nbsp;23, 2011, the Company entered into a credit agreement with a bank syndicate (the &#147;Credit
	Agreement&#148;) which provided for up to $130.0 million of unsecured revolving credit through October&nbsp;23, 2013. The Credit Agreement matured on October&nbsp;23, 2013, with no borrowings outstanding. The Company did not record any interest
	expense related to the Credit Agreement for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014. The Company recorded interest expense related to the Credit Agreement of $0.4 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As part of the GFI acquisition, the Company acquired a credit agreement as amended (the &#147;GFI Credit Agreement&#148;) with Bank of
	America, N.A. and certain other lenders, which provided for maximum revolving loans of up to $75.0 million. The amount outstanding was repaid by the Company on October&nbsp;2, 2015, prior to the sale of the Company&#146;s Trayport division. For the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company recorded interest expense related to the GFI Credit Agreement of $1.9 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	160
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage163"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D77592D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On October&nbsp;1, 2015, the Company entered into a previously authorized $150.0 million
	revolving credit facility (the &#147;Facility&#148;) with Cantor and borrowed $100.0 million under such facility (the &#147;Cantor Loan&#148;).&nbsp;The Cantor Loan bears interest at the rate of LIBOR plus 3.25% and may be adjusted based on
	Cantor&#146;s short-term borrowing rate then in effect plus 1%. The Facility has a maturity date of August&nbsp;10, 2017.&nbsp;The Company recorded interest expense related to the Cantor Loan of $0.8 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2015.&nbsp;The Cantor Loan was repaid by December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On December&nbsp;24, 2015 we entered into a committed unsecured credit
	agreement with Bank of America, N.A. The credit agreement provides for maximum revolving loans of $25.0 million through March&nbsp;24, 2016. The interest rate on this facility is LIBOR plus 200 basis points.&nbsp;There were no borrowings outstanding
	under the facility as of December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	19.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Compensation
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s Compensation Committee may grant various equity-based awards, including restricted stock units,
	restricted stock, stock options, limited partnership units and exchange rights for shares of the Company&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common stock upon exchange of limited partnership units and FPUs. On June&nbsp;2, 2015, at our Annual Meeting of
	Stockholders of the Company, the stockholders approved the Fifth Amendment and Restatement to the Amended and Restated Long Term Incentive Plan (the &#147;Equity Plan&#148;) to increase from 300&nbsp;million to 350&nbsp;million the aggregate number
	of shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock of the Company that may be delivered or cash settled pursuant to awards granted during the life of the Equity Plan. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the limit on the aggregate number of shares authorized to be
	delivered allowed for the grant of future awards relating to 180.0&nbsp;million shares. Upon vesting of RSUs, issuance of restricted stock or exercise of employee stock options, the Company generally issues new shares of the Company&#146;s
	Class&nbsp;A common stock.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, the Company granted exchangeability on
	26.9&nbsp;million, 18.0&nbsp;million and 9.8&nbsp;million limited partnership units for which the Company incurred non-cash compensation expense, before associated income taxes, of $231.4 million, $126.5 million and $57.0 million, respectively. The
	2015 amounts include a conversion of 90% of outstanding REUs and RPUs in December 2015 totaling 11.8&nbsp;million units and $114.0 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, the number of limited partnership units exchangeable into shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock at
	the discretion of the unit holder was 5.4&nbsp;million, 2.0&nbsp;million and 1.9&nbsp;million, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015
	and 2014, the notional value of the limited partnership units with a post-termination pay-out amount held by executives and non-executive employees, awarded in lieu of cash compensation for salaries, commissions and/or discretionary or guaranteed
	bonuses was approximately $30.4 million and $68.8 million, respectively. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, the aggregate estimated fair value of these limited partnership units was approximately $11.3 million and $11.8 million, respectively.
	The number of outstanding limited partnership units with a post-termination pay-out as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014 was approximately 3.3&nbsp;million and 9.8&nbsp;million, respectively, of which approximately 1.6&nbsp;million and
	6.9&nbsp;million were unvested.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Certain of the limited partnership units with a post-termination pay-out have been granted in connection
	with the Company&#146;s acquisitions. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, the aggregate estimated fair value of these acquisition related limited partnership units was $26.2 million and $24.2 million respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	161
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage164"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D77592D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Compensation expense related to limited partnership units with a post-termination pay-out amount
	is recognized over the stated service period. These units generally vest between three and five years from the date of grant. The Company recognized compensation expense, before associated income taxes, related to these limited partnership units
	that were not redeemed of $13.7 million, $6.5 million and $4.6 million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively. These are included in &#147;Compensation and employee benefits&#148; in the Company&#146;s consolidated
	statements of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Certain limited partnership units generally receive quarterly allocations of net income, which are cash
	distributed on a quarterly basis and generally contingent upon services being provided by the unit holders. The allocation of income to limited partnership units and FPUs was $28.3 million, $10.1 million and $62.6 million for the years ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The fair value of RSUs awarded to employees and directors is determined on the date of grant based on the
	market value of Class&nbsp;A common stock (adjusted if appropriate based upon the award&#146;s eligibility to receive dividends), and is recognized, net of the effect of estimated forfeitures, ratably over the vesting period. The Company uses
	historical data, including historical forfeitures and turnover rates, to estimate expected forfeiture rates for both employee and director RSUs. Each RSU is settled in one share of Class&nbsp;A common stock upon completion of the vesting period.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, the Company granted 0.7&nbsp;million, 1.0&nbsp;million and
	1.5&nbsp;million, respectively, of RSUs with aggregate estimated grant date fair values of approximately $5.7 million, $5.8 million and $4.9 million, respectively, to employees and directors. These RSUs were awarded in lieu of cash compensation for
	salaries, commissions and/or discretionary or guaranteed bonuses. RSUs granted to these individuals generally vest over a two- to four-year period.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For RSUs that vested during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, the Company withheld shares valued at $0.6 million, $1.2
	million and $1.2 million, respectively, to pay taxes due at the time of vesting.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015 and December&nbsp;31, 2014,
	the aggregate estimated grant date fair value of outstanding RSUs was approximately $9.5 million and $10.1 million, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Compensation expense related to RSUs, before associated income taxes, was approximately $5.3 million, $4.6 million and $5.8 million for the
	years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, there was approximately $8.7 million of total unrecognized compensation expense related to unvested RSUs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Restricted Stock
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Pursuant to the Global Partnership Restructuring Program in June 2013, the Company granted approximately 41&nbsp;million restricted shares of
	the Company&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common stock. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, the Company incurred non-cash, non-dilutive compensation charges of $304.1 million related to the redemption/exchange of partnership units and issuance of
	restricted shares, which was included in &#147;Allocation of net income and grants of exchangeability to limited partnership units and FPUs&#148; in the Company&#146;s consolidated statements of operations. Transferability of the shares of
	restricted stock is not subject to continued employment or service with the Company or any affiliate or subsidiary of the Company; however, transferability is subject to compliance with BGC Partners&#146; and its affiliates&#146; customary
	noncompete obligations. During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, approximately 270&nbsp;thousand shares and 390&nbsp;thousand shares, respectively, were forfeited in connection with this clause. The restricted shares are generally
	saleable by partners in five to ten years. Partners who agree to extend the length of their employment agreements and/or other contractual
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	162
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage165"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D77592D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	modifications sought by the Company are expected to be able to sell their restricted shares over a shorter time period. During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, the Company
	released the restrictions with respect to approximately 6.1&nbsp;million and 11.8&nbsp;million of such shares, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Deferred Cash Compensation
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As part of the acquisition of GFI, the Company now maintains a Deferred Cash Award Program which was adopted by GFI on February&nbsp;12, 2013,
	and provides for the grant of deferred cash incentive compensation to eligible employees. The Company may pay certain bonuses in the form of deferred cash compensation awards, which generally vest over a future service period. In addition, prior to
	the completion of the tender offer, GFI&#146;s outstanding RSUs were converted into the right to receive an amount in cash equal to $6.10 per unit, with such cash payable on and subject to the terms and conditions of the original vesting schedule of
	each RSU. The total compensation expense recognized in relation to the deferred cash compensation awards for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 was $23.1 million. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the total liability for the deferred cash
	compensation awards was $24.5 million, which is included in &#147;Accrued compensation&#148; on the Company&#146;s consolidated statements of financial condition. Total unrecognized compensation cost related to deferred cash compensation prior to
	the consideration of forfeitures, was approximately $32.3 million and is expected to be recognized over a weighted-average period of 1.27 years.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	There were 94&nbsp;thousand stock options exercised during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. The Company
	did not grant any stock options during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company did not record any compensation
	expense related to stock options for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 or 2013, as all of these options had vested in prior years. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, all of the compensation expense related to stock options was fully
	recognized.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table provides further details relating to the Company&#146;s stock options outstanding at December&nbsp;31,
	2015:
</P>

	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE:85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN:TOP">
	1
</SUP>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Operating leases are related to rental payments under various non-cancelable leases, principally for office space, net of sublease payments to be received. The total amount of sublease payments to be received is
	approximately $1.3 million over the life of the agreement.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE:85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN:TOP">
	2
</SUP>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Notes payable and collateralized borrowings reflects the issuance of $160.0 million of the 4.50% Convertible Notes due July&nbsp;15, 2016 (the $160.0 million represents the principal amount of the debt; the carrying
	value of the 4.50% Convertible Notes as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 was approximately $157.3 million), $112.5 million of the 8.125% Senior Notes due June&nbsp;26, 2042 (the $112.5 million represents the principal amount of the debt; the carrying value
	of the 8.125% Senior Notes as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 was approximately $109.1 million), $300.0 million of the 5.375% Senior Notes due December&nbsp;9, 2019 (the $300.0 million represents the principal amount of the debt; the carrying value of the
	5.375% Senior Notes as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 was approximately $296.1 million), $240.0 million of the 8.375% Senior Notes due July&nbsp;19, 2018 (the $240.0 million represents the principal amount of the debt; the carrying value of the 8.375%
	Senior Notes as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 was approximately $255.3 million), and $23.0 million of collateralized borrowings due March&nbsp;13, 2019. See Note 18&#151; &#147;Notes Payable, Collateralized and Short-Term Borrowings,&#148; for more
	information regarding these obligations, including timing of payments and compliance with debt covenants.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE:85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN:TOP">
	3
</SUP>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	The $196.1 million of interest on notes payable that are due in more than five years represents interest on the 8.125% Senior Notes. The 8.125% Senior Notes may be redeemed for cash, in whole or in part, on or after
	June&nbsp;26, 2017, at the Company&#146;s option, which may impact the actual interest paid.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE:85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN:TOP">
	4
</SUP>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Other contractual obligations reflect commitments to make charitable contributions, which are recorded as part of &#147;Accounts payable, accrued and other liabilities&#148; in the Company&#146;s consolidated statements
	of financial condition.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company is obligated for minimum rental payments under various non-cancelable operating leases,
	principally for office space, expiring at various dates through 2030. Certain of the leases contain escalation clauses that require payment of additional rent to the extent of increases in certain operating or other costs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, minimum lease payments under these arrangements are as follows (in thousands):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The lease obligations shown above are presented net of payments to be received under a non-cancelable
	sublease. The total amount of sublease payments to be received is approximately $1.3 million over the life of the agreement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In addition
	to the above obligations under non-cancelable operating leases, the Company is also obligated to Cantor for rental payments under Cantor&#146;s various non-cancelable leases with third parties, principally for office space and computer equipment,
	expiring at various dates through 2030. Certain of these leases have renewal terms at the Company&#146;s option and/or escalation clauses (primarily based on the Consumer Price Index). Cantor allocates a portion of the rental payments to the Company
	based on square footage used.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company also allocates a
	portion of the rental payments for which it is obligated under non-cancelable operating leases to Cantor and its affiliates. These allocations are based on square footage used (see Note 14&#151;&#147;Related Party Transactions,&#148; for more
	information).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Rent expense for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 was $52.8 million, $53.2 million and $51.0 million,
	respectively. Rent expense is included as part of &#147;Occupancy and equipment&#148; in the Company&#146;s consolidated statements of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In the event the Company anticipates incurring costs under any of its leases that exceed anticipated sublease revenues, it recognizes a loss
	and records a liability for the present value of the excess lease obligations over the estimated sublease rental income. The liability for future lease payments associated with vacant space, net of anticipated sublease rental income, was
	approximately $5.9&nbsp;million and $1.9 million, as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively, and is included as part of &#147;Accounts payable, accrued and other liabilities&#148; in the Company&#146;s consolidated statements of financial
	condition. The lease liability takes into consideration various assumptions, including prevailing rental rates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	164
</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D77592D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Contingent Payments Related to Acquisitions
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company completed acquisitions, whose purchase price included approximately 0.5&nbsp;million
	shares of the Company&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common stock (with an acquisition date fair value of approximately $4.1&nbsp;million), 1.8&nbsp;million limited partnership units (with an acquisition date fair value of approximately $15.2&nbsp;million) and
	$22.8&nbsp;million in cash that may be issued contingent on certain targets being met through 2018.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, the Company completed acquisitions, whose purchase price included approximately 2.0&nbsp;million shares of the Company&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common stock (with an acquisition date fair value of approximately $15.8 million),
	4.9&nbsp;million limited partnership units (with an acquisition date fair value of approximately $34.2 million) and $34.0 million in cash that may be issued contingent on certain targets being met through 2018.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, the Company completed acquisitions, whose purchase price included approximately 0.7&nbsp;million
	shares of the Company&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common stock (with an acquisition date fair value of approximately $3.1 million) and 0.3&nbsp;million limited partnership units (with an acquisition date fair value of approximately $1.6 million) that may be
	issued contingent on certain targets being met through 2018.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company has issued 6.2&nbsp;million shares
	of its Class&nbsp;A common stock, 2.0&nbsp;million of its limited partnership units and $10.9&nbsp;million in cash related to contingent payments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Contingencies
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In
	the ordinary course of business, various legal actions are brought and are pending against the Company and its subsidiaries in the U.S. and internationally. In some of these actions, substantial amounts are claimed. The Company is also involved,
	from time to time, in reviews, examinations, investigations and proceedings by governmental and self-regulatory agencies (both formal and informal) regarding the Company&#146;s businesses, which may result in judgments, settlements, fines,
	penalties, injunctions or other relief. The following generally does not include matters that the Company has pending against other parties which, if successful, would result in awards in favor of the Company or its subsidiaries.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Employment, Competitor-Related and Other Litigation
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	From time to time, the Company and its subsidiaries are involved in litigation, claims and arbitrations in the U.S. and internationally,
	relating to various employment matters, including with respect to termination of employment, hiring of employees currently or previously employed by competitors, terms and conditions of employment and other matters. In light of the competitive
	nature of the brokerage industry, litigation, claims and arbitration between competitors regarding employee hiring are not uncommon.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Legal reserves are established in accordance with FASB guidance on Accounting for Contingencies, when a material legal liability is both
	probable and reasonably estimable. Once established, reserves are adjusted when there is more information available or
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	165
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage168"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D77592D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	when an event occurs requiring a change. The outcome of such items cannot be determined with certainty. The Company is unable to estimate a possible loss or range of loss in connection with
	specific matters beyond its current accrual and any other amounts disclosed. Management believes that, based on currently available information, the final outcome of these current pending matters will not have a material adverse effect on the
	Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements and disclosures taken as a whole.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Letter of Credit Agreements
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has irrevocable uncollateralized letters of credit with various banks, where the beneficiaries are clearing organizations through
	which it transacted, that are used in lieu of margin and deposits with those clearing organizations. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company was contingently liable for $1.1 million under these letters of credit.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Risk and Uncertainties
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company generates revenues by providing financial intermediary, securities trading and brokerage activities, and commercial real estate
	services to institutional customers and by executing and, in some cases, clearing transactions for institutional counterparties. Revenues for these services are transaction-based. As a result, revenues could vary based on the transaction volume of
	global financial and real estate markets. Additionally, financing is sensitive to interest rate fluctuations, which could have an impact on the Company&#146;s overall profitability.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Guarantees
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The
	Company provides guarantees to securities clearinghouses and exchanges which meet the definition of a guarantee under FASB interpretations. Under these standard securities clearinghouse and exchange membership agreements, members are required to
	guarantee, collectively, the performance of other members and, accordingly, if another member becomes unable to satisfy its obligations to the clearinghouse or exchange, all other members would be required to meet the shortfall. In the opinion of
	management, the Company&#146;s liability under these agreements is not quantifiable and could exceed the cash and securities it has posted as collateral. However, the potential of being required to make payments under these arrangements is remote.
	Accordingly, no contingent liability has been recorded in the Company&#146;s consolidated statements of financial condition for these agreements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Indemnification
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In connection with the sale of eSpeed, the Company has indemnified NASDAQ for amounts over a defined threshold against damages arising from
	breaches of representations, warranties and covenants. In addition, in connection with the acquisition of GFI, the Company has indemnified the Directors and Officers of GFI. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, no contingent liability has been recorded in
	the Company&#146;s consolidated statements of financial condition for this indemnification, as the potential for being required to make payments under this indemnification is remote.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	21.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Income Taxes
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements include U.S. federal, state and local income taxes on the
	Company&#146;s allocable share of the U.S. results of operations, as well as taxes payable to jurisdictions outside the U.S. In addition, certain of the Company&#146;s entities are taxed as U.S. partnerships and are subject to the Unincorporated
	Business Tax (&#147;UBT&#148;) in New York City. Therefore, the tax liability or benefit related to the partnership income or loss except for UBT rests with the partners (see Note 2&#151;&#147;Limited Partnership Interests in BGC Holdings&#148; for
	discussion of partnership interests) rather than the partnership entity.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The provision for income taxes consisted of the following (in
	thousands):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
